nodes.text: Human information-processing capacity for simple unidimensional absolute judgments is limited to about seven categories (approximately 2.5 to 3 bits), but this limit can be extended by increasing stimulus dimensionality or by recoding and sequence processing

Absolute-judgment experiments treat the observer as a communication channel: input variance corresponds to amount of information and input-output covariance corresponds to transmitted information (channel capacity)

Method: Absolute judgment procedure - present a stimulus varying on one dimension (e.g., pitch), require an identification response, provide feedback, vary number of alternatives and compute transmitted information in bits
Result (pitch): Pollack's tone identification data show transmitted information rising with input up to ~2 bits then asymptoting near 2.5 bits (about six distinguishable pitches)
Claim: Channel capacities measured for various unidimensional sensory attributes cluster in a narrow range (approximately 1.6 to 3.9 bits; mean ~2.6 bits => ~6.5 categories)

Evidence: Empirical results - loudness ~2.3 bits (Garner), taste concentration ~1.9 bits (Beebe-Center et al.), visual position ~3.25-3.9 bits (Hake & Garner; Coonan & Klemmer), curvature as low as 1.6 bits (Pollack group), and other measures cluster near mean 2.6 bits
Claim: Adding independent stimulus dimensions increases channel capacity but with diminishing returns; multidimensional stimuli permit many more identifiable categories than one-dimensional stimuli

Evidence: Two-dimensional and higher results - dot-in-square (Klemmer & Frick) 4.6 bits (~24 positions), combined saltiness+sweetness 2.3 bits vs salt alone 1.9, pitch+loudness 3.1 bits vs each alone, Pollack & Ficks six-dimension auditory stimuli gave 7.2 bits (~150 categories); addition increases capacity but less than arithmetic sum

Claim: The span of immediate memory (short-term memory) is limited in number of items (chunks), typically about seven chunks, and is conceptually distinct from the information-based limit of absolute judgment

Evidence: Memory-span experiments (Hayes; Pollack) show that span in items is relatively constant across materials: binary digits span ~9, decimal digits ~8, monosyllabic words ~5, and transmitted information increases with bits per item rather than remaining constant
Claim: Distinction between bits and chunks â€” absolute judgment limit is a bits limit per judgment; immediate memory limit is a chunks limit largely independent of bits per chunk

Method and Evidence (recoding demonstration): Recoding groups lower-level units into larger chunks (Smith and self-experiment), e.g. grouping binary digits into octal/decimal names increases items remembered dramatically after practice
Result: Recoding increases bits per chunk and thus increases the total information retained; practiced recoding allowed recall of dozens of binary digits by reducing chunk count

Claim: The combination of simultaneous multidimensional encoding and successive judgments (sequences) plus recoding underlies how natural cognition reaches far beyond unidimensional limits (explains identification of many faces, words, objects)

Conclusion: While unidimensional absolute judgment capacities are small and fairly invariant, humans overcome these limits by (a) using relative judgments, (b) increasing stimulus dimensionality, and (c) using sequential judgments and recoding, and information theory provides a useful quantitative framework for these analyses
